# Creating a Right-Click Integration for Codebase to PDF Converter
I'll help you create a solution that allows you to convert Git repositories to PDF directly from your file manager's right-click menu in Linux (Hyprland).
## Overview
To achieve this, we'll need to:
1. Package our Java application as an executable JAR 2. Create a desktop entry for file manager integration 3. Set up the right-click context menu action
Let's break this down step by step:
## Step 1: Finalize the Java Application
First, we'll modify our Main class to handle being called from the file manager:
```java import java.io.File; import java.nio.file.Path; import java.nio.file.Paths; import java.util.List;
public class Main { public static void main(String[] args) { try { if (args.length < 1) { System.err.println("Usage: codepdf <directory_path> [output_file.pdf]"); System.exit(1); }
String path = args[0]; // Check if the path exists and is a directory File directory = new File(path); if (!directory.exists() || !directory.isDirectory()) { System.err.println("Error: The specified path is not a valid directory."); System.exit(1); }
// Default output name is the directory name + .pdf String outputFile = directory.getName() + ".pdf"; if (args.length >= 2) { outputFile = args[1]; }
// If output doesn't end with .pdf, add it if (!outputFile.toLowerCase().endsWith(".pdf")) { outputFile += ".pdf"; }
// If output path is not absolute, place it in the parent directory of the input File outputPath = new File(outputFile); if (!outputPath.isAbsolute()) { outputPath = new File(directory.getParentFile(), outputFile); outputFile = outputPath.getAbsolutePath(); }
System.out.println("Starting codebase to PDF conversion..."); System.out.println("Source directory: " + path); System.out.println("Output file: " + outputFile);
// Create components FileScanner scanner = new FileScanner(); SyntaxHighlighter highlighter = new SyntaxHighlighter(); PDFGenerator pdfGenerator = new PDFGenerator();
// Scan for code files List<File> codeFiles = scanner.scanDirectory(Paths.get(path)); System.out.println("Found " + codeFiles.size() + " code files.");
// Generate PDF pdfGenerator.generatePDF(codeFiles, highlighter, outputFile);
System.out.println("PDF generation complete! Output saved to: " + outputFile);
} catch (Exception e) { System.err.println("Error generating PDF: " + e.getMessage()); e.printStackTrace(); } } } ```
## Step 2: Package the Application
Create a Maven `pom.xml` that builds an executable JAR:
```xml <project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd"> <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>
<groupId>com.yourname</groupId> <artifactId>codepdf</artifactId> <version>1.0-SNAPSHOT</version>
<properties> <maven.compiler.source>24</maven.compiler.source> <maven.compiler.target>24</maven.compiler.target> <project.build.sourceEncoding>UTF-8</project.build.sourceEncoding> </properties>
<dependencies> <!-- iText Core --> <dependency> <groupId>com.itextpdf</groupId> <artifactId>itextpdf</artifactId> <version>5.5.13.3</version> </dependency>
<!-- XML Worker for HTML to PDF --> <dependency> <groupId>com.itextpdf.tool</groupId> <artifactId>xmlworker</artifactId> <version>5.5.13.3</version> </dependency> </dependencies>
<build> <plugins> <plugin> <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId> <artifactId>maven-assembly-plugin</artifactId> <version>3.6.0</version> <configuration> <archive> <manifest> <mainClass>com.yourname.Main</mainClass> </manifest> </archive> <descriptorRefs> <descriptorRef>jar-with-dependencies</descriptorRef> </descriptorRefs> <finalName>codepdf</finalName> <appendAssemblyId>false</appendAssemblyId> </configuration> <executions> <execution> <id>make-assembly</id> <phase>package</phase> <goals> <goal>single</goal> </goals> </execution> </executions> </plugin> </plugins> </build> </project> ```
Build the application with:
```bash mvn clean package ```
## Step 3: Create Installation Script
Create an installation script (`install.sh`) to set up the application:
```bash #!/bin/bash
# Define paths APP_NAME="CodePDF" JAR_NAME="codepdf.jar" INSTALL_DIR="$HOME/.local/share/codepdf" BIN_DIR="$HOME/.local/bin" ICON_PATH="$INSTALL_DIR/codepdf.png" DESKTOP_ENTRY="$HOME/.local/share/applications/codepdf.desktop" NAUTILUS_ACTIONS_DIR="$HOME/.local/share/nautilus/scripts" THUNAR_ACTIONS_DIR="$HOME/.config/Thunar/uca.xml" DOLPHIN_ACTIONS_DIR="$HOME/.local/share/kservices5/ServiceMenus"
# Create installation directory mkdir -p "$INSTALL_DIR" mkdir -p "$BIN_DIR"
# Copy JAR file cp "target/$JAR_NAME" "$INSTALL_DIR/$JAR_NAME"
# Create an executable script cat > "$BIN_DIR/codepdf" << EOF #!/bin/bash java -jar "$INSTALL_DIR/$JAR_NAME" "\$@" EOF
# Make it executable chmod +x "$BIN_DIR/codepdf"
# Create a simple icon (or you could copy your own icon file) echo "Creating application icon..." cat > "$INSTALL_DIR/codepdf.png" << EOF (Base64 encoded PNG data would go here - omitted for brevity) EOF
# Create desktop entry cat > "$DESKTOP_ENTRY" << EOF [Desktop Entry] Type=Application Name=CodePDF Comment=Convert code repositories to PDF Exec=codepdf %f Icon=$ICON_PATH Terminal=true Categories=Development;Utility; MimeType=inode/directory; Keywords=code;pdf;convert; EOF
# Now set up the right-click menu integration - this varies by file manager # We'll create scripts for multiple file managers
# Create directory for Nautilus scripts if it doesn't exist mkdir -p "$NAUTILUS_ACTIONS_DIR"
# Create Nautilus script cat > "$NAUTILUS_ACTIONS_DIR/Convert to PDF" << EOF #!/bin/bash codepdf "\$NAUTILUS_SCRIPT_CURRENT_URI" "\$NAUTILUS_SCRIPT_CURRENT_URI.pdf" EOF
chmod +x "$NAUTILUS_ACTIONS_DIR/Convert to PDF"
# For Dolphin (KDE) mkdir -p "$DOLPHIN_ACTIONS_DIR" cat > "$DOLPHIN_ACTIONS_DIR/codepdf.desktop" << EOF [Desktop Entry] Type=Service X-KDE-ServiceTypes=KonqPopupMenu/Plugin MimeType=inode/directory; Actions=ConvertToPDF;
[Desktop Action ConvertToPDF] Name=Convert to PDF Exec=codepdf %f Icon=$ICON_PATH EOF
# Check if we need to update Thunar's uca.xml (more complex) if [ -f "$THUNAR_ACTIONS_DIR" ]; then # Backup existing file cp "$THUNAR_ACTIONS_DIR" "$THUNAR_ACTIONS_DIR.bak"
# You'd need to create a proper XML modification here # This is simplified echo "Thunar configuration detected. Please add the following entry to your uca.xml file manually:" echo "<action>" echo " <name>Convert to PDF</name>" echo " <command>codepdf %f</command>" echo " <description>Convert code repository to PDF</description>" echo " <patterns>*</patterns>" echo " <directories/>" echo "</action>" fi
# Special case for Hyprland # Create an entry for Thunar if it exists if command -v thunar >/dev/null 2>&1; then mkdir -p "$HOME/.config/Thunar/uca.xml.d" cat > "$HOME/.config/Thunar/uca.xml.d/codepdf.xml" << EOF <action> <name>Convert to PDF</name> <command>codepdf %f</command> <description>Convert code repository to PDF</description> <patterns>*</patterns> <directories/> </action> EOF fi
echo "Installation complete!" echo "You may need to restart your file manager to see the new option." echo "Usage: Right-click on a code repository folder and select 'Convert to PDF'" echo "or run: codepdf /path/to/repository [output_file.pdf]" ```
## Step 4: Specific Integration for Hyprland
Since you mentioned you're using Hyprland, let's add specific support. Hyprland is a window manager, and the file manager you use with it could be various options like Thunar, PCManFM, or others.
For Thunar, which is commonly used:
```bash # Create a post-installation instruction file cat > post_install_hyprland.md << EOF # Post-Installation for Hyprland
Hyprland users typically use Thunar, PCManFM, or other file managers. Follow these steps to complete the integration:
## For Thunar File Manager
1. Open Thunar 2. Go to Edit â†’ Configure custom actions... 3. Click the + button to add a new action 4. Fill in the details: - Name: Convert to PDF - Description: Convert code repository to PDF - Command: codepdf %f 5. In the Appearance Conditions tab, check "Directories" 6. Click OK and close the dialog
## For PCManFM
1. Install PCManFM-specific integration by running: ``` mkdir -p ~/.local/share/file-manager/actions/ cat > ~/.local/share/file-manager/actions/codepdf.desktop << EOL [Desktop Entry] Type=Action Name=Convert to PDF ToolbarLabel=Convert to PDF Profiles=profile-zero;
[X-Action-Profile profile-zero] MimeTypes=inode/directory; Exec=codepdf %f Name=Default profile EOL ```
## General Usage
From the command line, you can always use: \`\`\` codepdf /path/to/git/repository [output.pdf] \`\`\` EOF ```

```markdown # CodePDF - Convert Code Repositories to PDF
A tool to convert entire code repositories (especially Git repositories) to PDF documents with syntax highlighting.
## Installation
Run the installation script:
```bash ./install.sh ```
## Usage
### From File Manager (Right-click)
1. Navigate to a Git repository in your file manager 2. Right-click on the repository folder 3. Select "Convert to PDF" from the context menu 4. The PDF will be created in the same location as the folder
### From Command Line
```bash codepdf /path/to/repository [output_file.pdf] ```
If output_file.pdf is not specified, the PDF will be saved as repositoryname.pdf in the parent directory.
## Features
- Syntax highlighting for code files - Table of contents with links to files - Skips binary files and common directories like .git, node_modules, etc. - Preserves directory structure in the PDF
## Configuration
Edit `~/.config/codepdf/config.properties` to customize:
- File extensions to include/exclude - Directories to skip - Syntax highlighting themes
## Troubleshooting
If the right-click option doesn't appear: - Make sure you've restarted your file manager - Check if your file manager needs additional configuration (see post_install_hyprland.md) - Ensure the script is executable ```
## Usage Example
Once installed, you can:
1. Navigate to a Git repository in your file manager 2. Right-click on the repository folder 3. Select "Convert to PDF" from the context menu 4. A terminal window will open showing progress 5. When complete, the PDF will be available in the parent directory
From the command line, you can run:
```bash codepdf ~/code/my-git-repo ```
